content: Not sure if this will pick up, I just heard something hilariously weird from a friend and remembered another story from my family. My mother told me this a few times about my father's grandmother, who was somewhat regarded as a Lapland shaman/witch (her grandfather was also regarded a respected witch in his village actually): My parents were at my grandparents farm, and when the cows/animals (don't remember if they were cows) needed to be contained, my father's grandmother simply walked a square around them. Needless to say, the cows stayed within that perimeter. And my friend's story: His great grandfather was fixing a church roof. Others with him said he should strap himself with a rope if he fell, to which he responded "don't worry, I'll slow down at the end". After some time, he did fall, but just stood up after hitting the ground. When questioned how he survived without getting hurt, he responded "I told you I'd slow down at the end". I hope these translate well enough.

content: Welllllll, Anne Boleyn's mother was an Ormond. Anne Boleyn gave birth to Elizabeth I, Queen of England. Elizabeth gave Sir Walter Raleigh the go-ahead to raid the Spanish Mane and put the Colony of Roanoke, and later Jamestown, into a place named "Virginia" after the Virgin Queen herself - - The rest is "history" - - Lady Elizabeth Howard, later Elizabeth Boleyn, Countess of Wiltshire and Ormonde (c. 1480 – 3 April 1538) was the eldest of the two daughters Thomas Howard, 2nd Duke of Norfolk had by his first wife Elizabeth Tilney. She was also a direct descendant of King Edward I.[1] She is most famous for having been the mother of Anne Boleyn, who became the second wife of King Henry VIII of England. As such, she was also the maternal grandmother of Queen Elizabeth I. The last name started out as a place name, Ormonde, in Ireland, which was given to some Duke named James Butler, the descendant of some Norman warrior-type, named James, who helped William the Conqueror fight his way across the the English Channel and conquer England in 1066. William was so pleased with James's good work, that he made James his body guard (Butler), so he became James (the) Butler. A later James Butler was sent to conquer and Ireland, which he mostly did, so he was given the area of Ormonde as fife, becoming James Butler, Duke of Ormonde. Ormonde included a place called Kilkenny, the home of the Kennedys. They often fought over the area but also inter-married. That is where Joseph Kennedy is from. Anyway, all of this, besides her beauty, is why Anne Boleyn's Protestant bloodline was certainly high enough that she could marry Henry VIII after he put aside Catherine of Argonne and broke from the Catholic Church - - Unfortunately, the Protestant/Catholic conflicts in Ireland mirror the Ormonde/Kennedy conflicts of old - - Oh, James Butler Hickco ck (Wild Bill) may also be a leaf from a very large family tree - - His mother was Polly Butler, daughter of a man named James Butler - - This message has been edited. But, then again, that's no so unusual for a family which produced the the Younger and the Dalton Brothers, is it?

content: “supposedly” my great-grandfather, (father’s side) from southern Italy, was challenged to a duel. Take 3-steps, turn and shoot; well he took 2-steps! Won the duel but shamed the family. Wealthy, with ties to the Vatican he arrived in America. He was approached by the San Giorgio brothers for a loan of 30k for them to start a business. When the money was to be returned they asked him if he “wanted in” on the business or did he want his money back. My great-grandmother said “NOODLES?? WHO THE HEWLL WOULD BUY NOODLES? Get the money back!!” And thus is the reason I’m on “this” side of the railroad tracks. choose joy each day

content: I don't know if this is weird, but Italians did this. When an Italian man dies, his brother would marry his widow. So, that is what my grandmother did. She was married to my great uncle, he died, she married my grandfather. She had a child from the first marriage, and 2 from the second marriage, my dad and my uncle. Her first child was called Tootsie, which made her my dads cousin/half sister. She was my second cousin/half aunt. And then her child, Linda would be my 3rd 1/2 cousin and my dads 1/2 neice. I think........ Now I am confused. Anyone got any suggestions as to what my relation is to my relatives??????

content: My Great-Grandmother married a travelling salesman from southern Missouri named Dalton in late 1800's. His relationship to the Dalton Gang has never been established. That's not the weird part...she had inherited the family farm in Hickman County, KY and made her husband-to-be sign a pre-nuptial agreement protecting her rights to the farm. This farm was left to her oldest son, my grandfather -- the same farm my mother grew up on.

content: I don't know if this is weird, but Italians did this. When an Italian man dies, his brother would marry his widow. So, that is what my grandmother did. She was married to my great uncle, he died, she married my grandfather. She had a child from the first marriage, and 2 from the second marriage, my dad and my uncle. Her first child was called Tootsie, which made her my dads cousin/half sister. She was my second cousin/half aunt. And then her child, Linda would be my 3rd 1/2 cousin and my dads 1/2 neice. I think........ Now I am confused. Anyone got any suggestions as to what my relation is to my relatives??????

content: Not sure if this will pick up, I just heard something hilariously weird from a friend and remembered another story from my family. My mother told me this a few times about my father's grandmother, who was somewhat regarded as a Lapland shaman/witch (her grandfather was also regarded a respected witch in his village actually): My parents were at my grandparents farm, and when the cows/animals (don't remember if they were cows) needed to be contained, my father's grandmother simply walked a square around them. Needless to say, the cows stayed within that perimeter. And my friend's story: His great grandfather was fixing a church roof. Others with him said he should strap himself with a rope if he fell, to which he responded "don't worry, I'll slow down at the end". After some time, he did fall, but just stood up after hitting the ground. When questioned how he survived without getting hurt, he responded "I told you I'd slow down at the end". I hope these translate well enough.

content: Welllllll, Anne Boleyn's mother was an Ormond. Anne Boleyn gave birth to Elizabeth I, Queen of England. Elizabeth gave Sir Walter Raleigh the go-ahead to raid the Spanish Mane and put the Colony of Roanoke, and later Jamestown, into a place named "Virginia" after the Virgin Queen herself - - The rest is "history" - - Lady Elizabeth Howard, later Elizabeth Boleyn, Countess of Wiltshire and Ormonde (c. 1480 – 3 April 1538) was the eldest of the two daughters Thomas Howard, 2nd Duke of Norfolk had by his first wife Elizabeth Tilney. She was also a direct descendant of King Edward I.[1] She is most famous for having been the mother of Anne Boleyn, who became the second wife of King Henry VIII of England. As such, she was also the maternal grandmother of Queen Elizabeth I. The last name started out as a place name, Ormonde, in Ireland, which was given to some Duke named James Butler, the descendant of some Norman warrior-type, named James, who helped William the Conqueror fight his way across the the English Channel and conquer England in 1066. William was so pleased with James's good work, that he made James his body guard (Butler), so he became James (the) Butler. A later James Butler was sent to conquer and Ireland, which he mostly did, so he was given the area of Ormonde as fife, becoming James Butler, Duke of Ormonde. Ormonde included a place called Kilkenny, the home of the Kennedys. They often fought over the area but also inter-married. That is where Joseph Kennedy is from. Anyway, all of this, besides her beauty, is why Anne Boleyn's Protestant bloodline was certainly high enough that she could marry Henry VIII after he put aside Catherine of Argonne and broke from the Catholic Church - - Unfortunately, the Protestant/Catholic conflicts in Ireland mirror the Ormonde/Kennedy conflicts of old - - Oh, James Butler Hickco ck (Wild Bill) may also be a leaf from a very large family tree - - His mother was Polly Butler, daughter of a man named James Butler - - This message has been edited. Last edited by: greywolfghost, Fri 03 April 2009 01:07 PM Wandering and Wondering

content: “supposedly” my great-grandfather, (father’s side) from southern Italy, was challenged to a duel. Take 3-steps, turn and shoot; well he took 2-steps! Won the duel but shamed the family. Wealthy, with ties to the Vatican he arrived in America. He was approached by the San Giorgio brothers for a loan of 30k for them to start a business. When the money was to be returned they asked him if he “wanted in” on the business or did he want his money back. My great-grandmother said “NOODLES?? WHO THE HEWLL WOULD BUY NOODLES? Get the money back!!” And thus is the reason I’m on “this” side of the railroad tracks. choose joy each day

content: Welllllll, Anne Boleyn's mother was an Ormond. Anne Boleyn gave birth to Elizabeth I, Queen of England. Elizabeth gave Sir Walter Raleigh the go-ahead to raid the Spanish Mane and put the Colony of Roanoke, and later Jamestown, into a place named "Virginia" after the Virgin Queen herself - - The rest is "history" - - Lady Elizabeth Howard, later Elizabeth Boleyn, Countess of Wiltshire and Ormonde (c. 1480 – 3 April 1538) was the eldest of the two daughters Thomas Howard, 2nd Duke of Norfolk had by his first wife Elizabeth Tilney. She was also a direct descendant of King Edward I.[1] She is most famous for having been the mother of Anne Boleyn, who became the second wife of King Henry VIII of England. As such, she was also the maternal grandmother of Queen Elizabeth I. The last name started out as a place name, Ormonde, in Ireland, which was given to some Duke named James Butler, the descendant of some Norman warrior-type, named James, who helped William the Conqueror fight his way across the the English Channel and conquer England in 1066. William was so pleased with James's good work, that he made James his body guard (Butler), so he became James (the) Butler. A later James Butler was sent to conquer and Ireland, which he mostly did, so he was given the area of Ormonde as fife, becoming James Butler, Duke of Ormonde. Ormonde included a place called Kilkenny, the home of the Kennedys. They often fought over the area but also inter-married. That is where Joseph Kennedy is from. Anyway, all of this, besides her beauty, is why Anne Boleyn's Protestant bloodline was certainly high enough that she could marry Henry VIII after he put aside Catherine of Argonne and broke from the Catholic Church - - Unfortunately, the Protestant/Catholic conflicts in Ireland mirror the Ormonde/Kennedy conflicts of old - - Oh, James Butler Hickco ck (Wild Bill) may also be a leaf from a very large family tree - - His mother was Polly Butler, daughter of a man named James Butler - - This message has been edited. But, then again, that's no so unusual for a family which produced the the Younger and the Dalton Brothers, is it?

content: “supposedly” my great-grandfather, (father’s side) from southern Italy, was challenged to a duel. Take 3-steps, turn and shoot; well he took 2-steps! Won the duel but shamed the family. Wealthy, with ties to the Vatican he arrived in America. He was approached by the San Giorgio brothers for a loan of 30k for them to start a business. When the money was to be returned they asked him if he “wanted in” on the business or did he want his money back. My great-grandmother said “NOODLES?? WHO THE HEWLL WOULD BUY NOODLES? Get the money back!!” And thus is the reason I’m on “this” side of the railroad tracks. choose joy each day

content: It was 1960 and I was a little kid of 6 years old. We went up to Prince Edward Island, Canada, and attended a wake. This is when I learned a wake refers from when someone dies everybody stays up all night and the deceased is laid out in his home. My father and some other idiots had been plastered by now. At first they put a can of beer in the body's hand. Then they hung a cigarette in his mouth. Later they tried to stand him up and drink with it some more. They all were singing and carrying on like those I have never imitated. This message has been edited. Last edited by: scpd3045, Fri 03 April 2009 06:03 PM

content: --- Let`s See, my ol man`s middle name was, integrity.. my 1958, Indian Summer Camp name was, "Smartazz kid runs with scissors". --- Un-related -- Been to Gettysburg twice as gun commander for Confederate Artilery. - Fascinating story about "Miss Jennie Wade", the only civilian woman to be killed in the 3 day battle. She is the ONLY civilian to be granted a MILITARY flag by Congress & to serviced by the military year round. - Gettysburg, a must see for your family. content: I don't know if this is weird, but Italians did this. When an Italian man dies, his brother would marry his widow. So, that is what my grandmother did. She was married to my great uncle, he died, she married my grandfather. She had a child from the first marriage, and 2 from the second marriage, my dad and my uncle. Her first child was called Tootsie, which made her my dads cousin/half sister. She was my second cousin/half aunt. And then her child, Linda would be my 3rd 1/2 cousin and my dads 1/2 neice. I think........ Now I am confused. Anyone got any suggestions as to what my relation is to my relatives??????

content: My Great-Grandmother married a travelling salesman from southern Missouri named Dalton in late 1800's. His relationship to the Dalton Gang has never been established. That's not the weird part...she had inherited the family farm in Hickman County, KY and made her husband-to-be sign a pre-nuptial agreement protecting her rights to the farm. This farm was left to her oldest son, my grandfather -- the same farm my mother grew up on.
